awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Preventing Evolutionary Failure in Synthetic Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
1554179
Barrick, Jeffrey E.

Synthetic biology applies engineering principles to create living systems with predictable and useful behaviors from collections of standardized genetic parts. However, living systems - unlike mechanical devices - inevitably evolve when their DNA sequences accumulate copying errors, often resulting in "broken" cells that no longer function as they were programmed. This project will address this problem by better characterizing how engineered cells evolve and using this information to design DNA sequences and host cells that are reinforced against unwanted evolution.  Decreasing the incidence of evolutionary failures in bioengineering will have broad benefits: increasing the complexity of DNA-based devices that can be constructed and used for the sustainable production of biofuels and drugs; limiting the potential dangers of unpredictable evolution when genetically modified organisms are used in future applications outside of the laboratory; and inspiring a new generation of students to pursue careers in science and technology by improving the chances that their first synthetic biology projects are successful.

For efforts ranging in scale from constructing small genetic circuits and metabolic pathways to international research consortia rebuilding entire microbial genomes, stopping - or at least slowing - evolution would greatly improve the efficiency of biological engineering. This research will: (i) create software to predict evolutionary weaknesses (failure modes) in the DNA sequences encoding devices so that they can be avoided at the design stage, (ii) develop high-throughput experimental techniques based on next-generation DNA sequencing to more fully characterize these failure modes and improve these predictions, and (iii) use directed evolution and genome editing to create variants of organisms that are common chassis for synthetic biology with reduced mutation rates. These research activities are integrated with education by supporting an undergraduate International Genetically Engineered Machine (iGEM) team at the University of Texas at Austin and their graduate student mentors. They will standardize methods for measuring the evolutionary reliability of biological devices and improve the stability of popular genetic parts in the Registry of Standard Biological Parts, a resource used worldwide in education and research. Hispanic students and women will specifically be involved in the iGEM team so that this project directly contributes to the development of a diverse STEM workforce.
This CAREER award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Synthetic biologists are engineering cells into factories that sustainably manufacture chemicals and foods, biosensors that monitor and protect the environment, and therapeutics that treat disease and improve human health. Because engineered cells are living systems that replicate, they can mutate and evolve. In particular, "broken" cells with loss-of-function mutations often have a growth advantage because they no longer divert some of their resources away from replication to an engineered function. Cells with these mutations can rapidly outcompete properly functioning cells. This project characterized how evolutionary failure of engineered cells affects the reliability and productivity of synthetic biology, and it developed methods for stabilizing engineered DNA sequences and cells against unwanted evolution.

1. Modeling Evolutionary Failure of an Engineered Cell Population

The rate of evolutionary failure of an engineered cell population depends on two factors: the burden of the engineered function (how much it slows cellular replication) and the mutation rate (how often changes in a cell's DNA sequence arise that alleviate this burden by "breaking" the engineered function). This project created simulations and an interactive website to display how long an engineered function will be maintained given different burden and mutation rate combinations. These simulations also demonstrate how the rarity and randomness of mutations can make the time until failure highly variable due to chance during scale-up of a population from a single cell to a colony on an agar plate to a small lab culture and finally to a large bioreactor.

2. Designing DNA Sequences that Are Robust Against Evolution

Rates of evolutionary failure can be reduced by avoiding using certain DNA sequences and combinations of genetic parts that are prone to mutations or more burdensome than they need to be in order to accomplish the intended function. This project created the Evolutionary Failure Mode Calculator, an open-source web tool that identifies several types of unstable sequences in a proposed design so that a user can redesign their DNA to avoid mutations. Engineering cells by cutting and pasting DNA sequences together into plasmids can inadvertently carry over pieces of DNA with cryptic or forgotten functions that cause burden or interfere with the intended function. This project developed an open-source web tool, pLannotate, that displays leftover fragments of genetic parts that may lead to unnecessary burden or otherwise affect plasmid function.

3. Developing Reduced Mutation Bacterial Cell Chassis

Cells can vary in the types and rates of mutations that occur in their DNA sequences. This project developed a directed evolution procedure that can create microbial cells with reduced mutation rates. This procedure was used to discover Escherichia coli with lower-than-natural plasmid mutation rates associated with mutations in enzymes that copy DNA, housecleaning functions that eliminate mutagens, and metabolic processes that damage DNA. This project also engineered a low mutation version of the bacterium Acinetobacter baylyi by deleting all transposons, selfish DNA elements that replicate and insert into other genes, from its genome. A portable system for repressing transposons was shown to be capable of similarly lowering mutation rates.

Broader Impacts

Methods that make engineered DNA sequences and cells more robust against evolutionary failure improve the productivity and reach of synthetic biology. By stabilizing the foundation of this emerging engineering discipline, this project contributed to enabling future work in which even more complex and challenging functions will be engineered into living cells for applications in industry, agriculture, and medicine.

This project supported the development of a diverse STEM workforce through training graduate students and integrating research with two educational programs for undergraduate students at UT Austin: the Microbe Hackers experiential learning course that is part of the Freshman Research Initiative and an iGEM synthetic biology team. Students from both groups contributed to research projects and helped to disseminate results, including through work that was recognized by a Best Measurement award at the 2019 iGEM Jamboree. For example, the iGEM team described how plasmids encoding fluorescent proteins in a measurement kit rapidly evolved to give unreliable results, measured the burden of >300 genetic parts on cells, and added this information to web pages in the iGEM Registry of Standard Biological Parts to educate the synthetic biology community about evolutionary failure.
